number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												I'm going to be frank and say that this is probably one of the best-written video games I've ever played.  With a bevy of plot-twists and an engaging system of character building in d20 format, Knights of the Old Republic 2 grabbed my attention and never dropped it.Obsidian's trademark writing style is in full tilt here as they show off their amazing ability to elaborate on characters such that you know precisely who you're talking to in-depth beyond surface layers that most companies would present, and unlike the way KOTOR 1 was handled by Bioware, you're not a moustache-twirling cartoonish loony if you go for the Dark Side choices.The game is deeply philosophical and looks into what it really means to be a Force Sensitive person; it provides an interesting perspective into the nature of the Force that in my opinion isn't really seen very much elsewhere via both the insight and backstory of one of your companions and your own personal journey through the story.The biggest cons that I would give to it are that it's unpolished.  I'm not sure if Obsidian built themselves up over an indian burial ground or what happened but it seems like these guys just -cannot- catch a break when it comes to actually getting enough time to finish their product before it gets rushed to the market.  There's a lot of amazing content that's restored by the appropriately named Sith Lords Restoration Project and its sister issues, including scraps of what was left of an -entire droid planet- and several storylines that were kiboshed and remained partially in or were stripped completely from the remainder of the game.  This adds several hours of playtime and is really worth it in the long run if you want the full experience even if you can easily tell for the most part what's been spliced back in by a modding team (the scenes in many cases weren't complete).Personally, uh, if you're going to go for the complete experience, though, I'd recommend you skip the Droid Planet. Last I checked that fan-project was unstable and buggy, not to mention really long-slogging and full of lag.  Might be worth it for a completionist, but there just wasn't enough data left to make it seem worthwhile.  Correct me if I'm wrong, folks.Anyway, finishing up, get this game.  It's worth it just to sit back and listen to some of the conversations.  The gameplay's just a plus.

Big, Bold and Beautiful One of, if not the best Star Wars games to date, and an essential addition to anyone with love for the Star Wars universe or RPG games. Runs surprisingly smooth on Windows 10, looks beautiful in 1080p, and is an all-round great storytelling experience that keeps players invested in the characters they create. The soundtrack (like KOTOR before it) is just beautiful - reflecting the locations and characters perfectly. I was also rather impressed with the improvements to customization whether it be aesthetic or abilities. I'm currently back into my 4th playthrough, and still thoroughly enjoying all the game has to offer. If you're currently fence sitting about purchasing, jump right in and I guarentee you won't be dissapointed.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Knight of the Old Republic II.This game. The more you play it, the more it gets better. This belongs to the Underrated category, being superior than its predecessor, biowares KoTor.This game sets up few years after the events of the original KoTor game. This Time you play as "the exile" an ex jedi who followed Revan to war against the Mandalorian threath. On your journey you discover a terrible thruth: You are the key to kill the force.This new concept on killing the force is really something new in star wars. Every single star wars game is about ruling something. Lets talk about locations.Tutorial:  This game has an skippable tutorial level, but i recomend you to play it, since there are few mechanics that are different than the Biowares KoTor. The level is located inside the Ebon Hawk. Revan's ship from the last game.1st level. Peragus mining asteroid.Wow. I really enjoyed this level. You face countlets of enemies and try to find out why everyone is mysteriously dead. Venturing deeper this mysterious dead rock you meet your 3 first companions. The level desing is great lightings are marvelous.2nd. Level. Telos shipyard and surface.This location acts like a pit stop. A location for you to catch up what has happened during these years and why there are no more jedis. As location this is the weakest on my opinion. There is much to do, but at that time of the game I really wanted to get the hell out of there. Still enjoyable.(Next locations will be mentioned briefly, because these I dont want to spoil)Dxun moon, Onderon, Nar Shaddaa, Dantooine, Korriban, Malachor.All of them have enjoyable areas. many cool enemies and really beautifull landscapes.Companions: The companions are ALL good. Best written characters in star wars. Depends on your affection to them they are seen wandering around the Ebon Hawk. They argue against eachothers and even plot against some characters. And for the first time it really matters wich gender you pick. Female: gets the Diciple.Male: gets Brianna.And even your Dark/Lightside affects 2 companions. Hanharr and MiraIf you are evil you get the mad wookiee. If you are a saint, a good bounty hunter will aproach you.These details add replay-value, because they add their own story to the game and own dilemas that you have to solve.Many people dislike this game, but to be honest Obsidian made an amazing job with this one. Lack of time and money made the game shorter and many good content were cut off from the final product. This is one of the greatest star wars games that i have played (I have played many). From PC tie fighter to the newest Star wars Battlefront. This Game is on my top 3. Maybe even the Best star wars game that i have played. Surpassing KoTor and Jedi Knight serie.Overall score: 9/10Try it? yesBuy it? yesHave physical copy? YES

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												[NOTE: this review assumes that the player will use the The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod (TSLRCM) from the game's workshop. This reviewer think that said mod is a necessary part of the game at this point and can't be separated from the vanilla game itself]Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords is a sequel to the original roleplaying game by BioWare by Obsidian Entertainment. Set once again centuries before the Star Wars' movies timeline, The Sith Lords' story picks up immediately where the story of the first game ended: the galactic Republic is now in disarray due to the Jedi civil war and Sith forces still run rampart through its planets, with the Jedi order in ruin and no Force practicioneers in sight. You take the role of a Jedi who has been exiled from his/her order before the civil war and your objective is to survive the dark forces coming after you and discover the true reasons behind your punishment and the origin of your peculiar connection to the Force.As far the gameplay goes, the Sith Lords manages to be a better roleplaying game than its predecessor. Several gameplay elements have been overhauled or change to support different styles of play and to truly allow you to build a character following your tastes AND be able to overcome the game's challenges. While in the first Knights of the Old Republic the balance favored pure melee Jedi characters, now other specializations and characters have a chance too: enemies are less prone to resist Force powers, making them viable for pure damage or CC, and both melee weapons and blasters can now benefit from unique upgrades that really give lightsabers a run for their money. It's worth mentioning however that the Sith Lords' endgame somehow favors caster characters: by that point in the game the Force points (your mana, if you will) regen rateo has become gargantuan, allowing you to spam damaging spells or incapacitating effects ad nauseam (something that becomes really useful, since the last portion of the game are a series of straight fights against crowds of opponents).The Sith Lords' main new gameplay gimmick is the influence system. The companions you travel with will react to your actions and choices, approving them or else following their own moral compass and objectives: therefore, your influence with them will increase or decrease accordingly. Having an high influence with a character means unlocking new conversation options and even the possibility to turn him/her into a Jedi. The main downside of the influence system is however that the parameter is increased mainly during world events, so you'll manage to get a good influence with the characters you'll use most only. Another gimmick the game likes to throw at you is the sudden playable characters changes: at many points during the game you will be forced to put aside your main character to play in the shoes of one or more companions. While these sequences are interesting in their own right and have their place in the main story, they can easily becomes frustrating if you are forced to play a character you are not familiar with or whom you neglected beforehead.Knights of the Old Republic II is also infamous for the somehow shifting quality of its levels. There are some levels that are universally loathed by the playerbase, with the two main examples being Peragus (which is quite long for being your first proper level after the tutorial prologue, with the story going on at a snail's pace) and Nar Shaddaa (which is another planet that takes far too long as far as the main quest goes, requires a lot of backtracking and has a brutal endgame). Also, the final area of the game, Malachor V, hasn't many fans around due to having been hit the worst by the rushed development cycle and consisting in a series of straight fights against several opponents with little to none interaction or exploration involved.Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic II - The Sith Lords remains a very divisive game in pretty much ever aspect, even the story and the setting. Some people like the deconstruction the writers wanted to pull off on the Star Wars canon as a whole and the main morality system of the series, while others find it pretentious and too much shoehorned. Some people see the game as an incomplete, rushed mess, while others can somehow get past the blatantly missing part and enjoy what they got their hands on. Personally, while the Sith Lords could had been a far stronger sequel and a Star Wars RPG in its own right, I found myself enjoying it more often than not due to the high level of the writing, the refined and more custom gameplay and its central interesting themes

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												This may be the single most underrated video game of all time. In fairness, the original version (as I played it on my Xbox) was indeed a bit of a mess. I have no idea why this game was recently updated with full modern game amenities (steam cloud, achievements, controller support, workshop, etc) but it's one of the happiest gaming surprises I've ever experienced. Playing through this game again - this time with the restored content mod - was an awesome opportunity I never thought I would have.If the philosophy of Star Wars has ever interested you in a deeper way, this game was written for you. The way the story deconstructs the Force - what it means to be a Jedi, a Sith, what generalizations those titles reflect, and what meaning they contain is infinitely fascinating, and I find myself reflecting on the scenarios and characters introduced in this game more so than any other Star Wars property (and most science fiction in general).If you want to unravel the true mysteries of the Force - or just want to find out what happens after the first KotOR - this game is definitely worth your time.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2013
												In my opinion, the second game far outweighs the first one.  It improves everything the first game did, in every way.  Some people say it was unfinished, at least that's the rumor, and to an extent it is true.  However, I've completed this game many many times, don't let Steam fool you, and I can honestly say I"ve never encountered any real bugs or glitches.  The last time I completed it, I installed the Lost Content Mod (do a Google Search).  The Lost Content Mod makes the game a lot different, in a good way, but you'd only really notice the big differences if you're like me and you've beat it multiple times already.  Still I highly recommend you install it.The resolution is low because this is an old game, but you can rig it to go higher I believe.  I could write a full professional review here detailing all the solid points as well as the highs and lows of the game, but I'm not.  It's a fantastic role-playing game, and it's the best Star Wars story I've experienced so far.  It's been so many years since I first played this on original Xbox, and I'm still finding new things to love about it to this day.  There's much replayability, especially if you're into games like Mass Effect, and once again the Lost Content mod adds quite a bit to the experience.  Plenty of role-playing afficionados will likely claim that the first game is superior, but you can take it from a lifetime Star Wars fan: everything about this game really just captures me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												The first in a series of flawed diamonds by Obsidian.It was a warm summer's day when Bioware was busy working on other projects that they had started and soon discovered that they couldn't fit KoToR 2 into their projects. So they walked over to Obsidian entertainment and knocked on the door and formed an agreement to allow Obsidian to develop KoTor 2 for them. However, Bioware was impatient so they only had a year of development time to work on it. Obsidian sat down and immediatley got to work, as the studio only had around 10-15 people working in it at the time, all the time they had was invaluable. Lots of time was spent making assests that were never put into the final game, thus, time was spent. Obsidians greatest strength was in the writing department, as they did not view moral choices just as a simple "black & white" dialogue option. No, to them it was all grey, as in you could save the princess but you had to let the dragon destroy the village choices. In Obsidian's characters, everybody has a personality that expressed what kind of person every character was, just through talking to the player. Obsidian were true nobles in this field.As Obsidian got closer to the deadline, more and more assests were cut from the final game. Leaving the original vision a "Treasure in a deep sea of monsters." Many assests were cut and untested and unfiltered bugs were present due to the short QA testing period that was received. Distraught as they were at the final product, Obsidian regretted spending too much time developing certain assests of the game and too little time in other parts. With fear of negative criticism from the press, fans, and of course Bioware, Obsidian took to the internet to see what the public was saying about KoToR 2. To their surprise, the fans loved it with negative criticism going toward the number of many bugs and glitches that were present, and postive criticism going toward everything included in the writing, especially the dialogue from party members like Kreia and Atton. Given the number of people working at Obsidian at the time and the amount of time they had, Obsidian managed to turn a Hardees into a Jack-in-the-box. Kreia even went on to win "Most Original character of the year" from Gamespy that year.Obsidian learning from their first project, went on to make memorable game such as Alpha Protocol, Neverwinter Nights 2 + Expansions, Fallout: New Vegas (which suffered a similar experience), and soon to be South Park: The Stick of truth and Pillars of Eternity. If you like RPG's with great characters and grey morality, then Obsidian has it down.

I could write a full professional review here detailing all the solid points as well as the highs and lows of the game, but I'm not.  It's a fantastic role-playing game, and it's the best Star Wars story I've experienced so far.  It's been so many years since I first played this on original Xbox, and I'm still finding new things to love about it to this day.  There's much replayability, especially if you're into games like Mass Effect, and once again the Lost Content mod adds quite a bit to the experience.  Plenty of role-playing afficionados will likely claim that the first game is superior, but you can take it from a lifetime Star Wars fan: everything about this game really just captures me.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												In general everyone seems to think KoTOR is better than TSL. I am not among the general.That said, TSL has some buggy stuff where suddenly you and all your people are Sith aligned. CTDs. The script language does not always make sense, and the paths forward are not always clear. The said, the scope here is almost as impressive as the philosophy.You are again a mysterious stranger. You don't wait as long to find out who you are. Mentored by an old Jedi, once again you assemble a team and make choices. Some of these forward your relationship to gain character backstory. Some of these increase your leanings. Again, you decide how you want to play: Kill 'em all and let the force sort them out, be at peace with anything that doesn't aggro you, or meh.The depth of the story, though, is impressive. There is betrayal, Jedi gone rogue, some dude who is literally falling apart after trying to kill his master, and a boss that consumes the force for sustenance. They all tie-in to the greater story explored in the novels of who is Revan, was he good or bad (or she, again, the canon is overthrown), and what force exists beyond what can be seen by the Jedi council that threatens all of Republic space? You can also help "rebuild" the Mandalorians, train your own Jedi/Sith team, and destroy a planet. It's really cool. Toss in the restored content and other mods (just like KoTOR), and you've got serious replayability.recommended buy, but again, wait for a sale. It happens a lot. Save them dolladolla bills.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												So I've owned KOTOR 2 for many years now. I got it for Christmas the year it came out, same as the original. Since then, I've owned 2 more copies of the game, one on the original xBox, and then this version on Steam.First off, this game is amazing. Comparing it to the original, it keeps a lot of the good, and makes most of it better. Don't come into this game expecting an amazing story based on your character, however, because rather than that, it gives you an amazing (and in my opinion, better) story based on how your character's actions affect your companions and the galaxy as a whole.While this game's combat and mechanics are basically the same as the original KOTOR, several mechanics are much deeper than before. Upgrading is greatly expanded, giving many options for creating your ultimate weapons. Creating and Breaking Down items has been added, forcing you to decide on what to sell and what to break down into components, in order to create another weapon or item. And since this game focuses on companions, an influence mechanic has been implemented into your interactions with them. Now, what you say and do can change how your companions look at you and change their light and dark side orientation.Now, for the bad. This game is packed full of amazing content, but due to some issues, the game is left… unfinished. The final few areas are lacking. The developers were rushed for the end of the game, and it feels lacking. Luckily, there is a fix for this. The Restored Content Mod is available here on Steam, and helps to fill in the gaps and slightly clear up the problems the developers left behind.As for the quality of this version, it is superior to the other two I owned. The others were riddled with bugs, and frequently crashed. This version hasn't crashed once in the hundred hours or so that I've played it. On top of that, it is extremely easy to get mods for the game, some of which are very important (such as the Restored Content Mod), for creating a better experience for your game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												TL;DR: Beautifully made game, deep story. Fixes below. You're all meatbags. All hail the Gizka's.Absolutely one of my most favorite games of all time (and I play many games). This game is a gem of both RPG's and the star wars universe because of the amazing depth in storytelling and the way it engages me and allows me to make my own choices, something I've found lacking in games recently. Originally I owned both KOTORs on xbox (and shamelessly logged  hundreds  of hours into each) and rebought them on steam for the third time (original disk broke) just to play it again.---What you need to know---Yes, the game is buggy. This was made for much earlier versions of windows and you're likely to suffer the odd glitch every now and then. HOWEVER there is, of course, a fix! A few of the catch-all fixes that I've used and have worked for the PC versions are as follows; The  swconfig  file which can be found in your game folder installation directory. Open this and check 1) Enable Hardware Mouse and 2) Disable Movies. You miss a little disabling movies and so you may want to go back and uncheck it and see whether it works for you. Last resort you can watch them through the main menu or through the magic of the internet. Editing the "swkotor2" configuration file, found in the same directory. Should fullscreen not work out for you as it didnt for me then paste the following line below [Graphics Options] --> AllowWindowedMode=1Then change the "Fullscreen=1" to "Fullscreen=0" and you'll be playing in windowed mode. Enabling compatability mode. Not difficult to do, which compatability you use depends on your system.The internet is your friend! By no means is this a comprehensive list, just the major ones that I've confirmed to work for myself or others.Truly this is a fantastic game and easily worth its price. Also look out for the Restored Content mod, which flushes out the story to its true potential and adds so much great stuff to the game! Now quit sitting around and buy the game already meatbags.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												TL; DR: KotOR II is excellent, but unfinished. A must play for Star Wars and/or RPG fans. Play through it once without the Restored Content Mod and play through it again with the mod installed.I have owned this game for a very long time. I originally played this game countless times on a disc, so my Steam hours do not accurately reflect the time I have spent with this game. I am one of those people that say that this game is better than the original (although the original is extremely good too).Let's get this out of the way first. Knights of the Old Republic II is an unfinished game. It was rushed to release to meet a Holiday release date. As a result of this, many sections of the game were cut out entirely, including an entire planet, along with vital story dialogue with characters and an ending that actually makes some sense. I am aware that there is a mod that restores a good chunk of the cut content called The Sith Lord Restored Content Mod (which is very good by the way), but I will bring that up into more detail later.Take the Star Wars formula that you know (Jedi = Good, Sith = Bad) and completely flip it on its head. It doesn't do a complete turn around, but you start thinking of the Jedi and the Sith more in shades of grey than in one being absolutely good and the other absolutely evil. You get more of a nuanced education in the Force from one of the best Star Wars characters ever, Kreia. Let's be honest here, Kreia is absolutely the best character in this game and is probably one of the best Star Wars characters ever, yes you heard that right.In KotOR II, you play as the Jedi Exile, a former Jedi Knight that was kicked out of the order due to his/her involvement in the Mandalorian Wars. You were one of the Jedi that followed Revan and Malak off to war, and you were also the only Jedi that returned to face judgment. Ten years have passed since then and you return to find a threat facing the galaxy that hides in the shadows. What follows is a galaxy spanning quest in the same ship as the first game collecting companions to aid you in this threat while rediscovering your connection to the Force. It is one of the most unique takes on the Star Wars license.But, as was said earlier, it was rushed to meet a deadline. A lot of vital content was cut from the final release, but the files were still in the game. A team of modders took it upon themselves to restore this content (what they could, anyway), and it is a crime that Obisidian was not given enough time to finish this game properly. However, I do recommend that new players do not play through the game first with the Restored Content Mod and save it for a second playthrough. Playing through it first unfinished and then switching to the mod gives you a much better idea of exactly how much stuff was cut, and how important the cut content really is. If you are a fan of Star Wars, or of RPGs in general, then there is no question, KotOR II is a must buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic II is a very special game to me. It has a well written storyline with plenty of side quests. It has really solid gameplay especially for its age. Being able to take the turn based combat into real time freely while preparing the next few actions you want to take in combat is a brilliant mechanic. The story aside from towards the end where it just felt rushed, was actually better compared to Knights of the Old Republic I. Gameplay was heavily improved over the original game and the companions you have felt just as well developed. The tag story rich is no understatement. This in my opinion is one of the best RPG's of all time. A lot of people find you towards the end of the game are a bit strong at least within my circle of friends who have played the game. Which I find in certain parts is true but Kotor II really does bring a moderate challenge in its gameplay. I felt many of the boss battles were a pretty entertaining. Towards the end i'm not ashamed to say I abused Force Lightning Storm and some kiting strategies to deal with a lot the enemies that i'd be fighting in groups of 5 or more. The game's lightside darkside system as always is just so well designed. My favorite part of my playthrough was me trying to perspective how i'd interact with these characters thrown into the scenario of the Jedi Exile and acting on my opinion and not a light side or dark side choice.The crafting system is really well done I loved the lightsaber crafting options and skill system requirements for crafting. The skill tree for combat was amazing a lot of diversity and freedom. Getting to the force skill tree it's in my opinion one of the best skill tree's i've ever had in a game really one of my favorite parts of the whole game is the amazing force abilities and the progression they make. I only wish there was more because it was so much fun achieving these force powers. Kotor II is the dream sequel to Kotor I honestly all it makes me want is for another one. We all pray for Kotor III because of how amazing these gems of the past are. There are still a few flaws obviously in the game glitches mostly. The biggest issue the game has is its age. Not because of graphics but more because of modern optimization.To start with the issues is how often it crashes. If it crashes at the loading screen for you or something i'm sorry never seen that issue happen to me once fix its resolution in its files. I found the game crashes from being full screen in very specific cutscenes often in world transitions. Hitting alt enter in the loading screen windowed modes the game. This fixed all of my crash issues i'd often just save before a cutscene since in most games they're obviously coming and alt enter if it crashed so I could enjoy my full screen glory. (When it didn't crash happened like 5 times throughout the game no mods installed)The inventory system itself is very poorly sorted wish I had a search bar to find items or certain stat types not even a big issue though. Abusable medpack tricks like activating one during your healing round inside your inventory while casting heal. Albeit I like this trick since it helped me in a situations where I failed to pay attention to gameplay and got chunked down. The AI for companions is pretty bad they like to run into fights repeatedly forcing my to loop between characters to continuously get them away from enemies as they'd run back in on 10% health and no force points. Good times with that I can say that much.Lightsaber on lightsaber combat damage is a little bit too high. For boss battles and even regular lightsaber combat I could say even having half damage on lightsaber damage. Maybe by having a special melee defense perk to reduce the damage would be nice since my Master Flurry Shreds boss HP. While bosses shred my HP way to quick kind of reducing the excitement of drawn out boss battle. This is the biggest fault of the combat system in the entire game and it's still not even that bad. I don't know if there is a mod for this but my final complaint is these older games often have no map markers which helps exploration but is more irritating when you have no idea where to go and the journal isn't helping much. I found this an occasional issue that can be extremely annoying. My last real issue besides the rushed ending is the slow start definitely wish I could skip that start.Also not enough Sith using force lightning abilities that ♥♥♥♥♥ top tier. (Fighting the Sith was really cool in all seriousness)Summing up review in a Tldr;Pro's:-Good RPG gameplay-Amazing Real time turn combat-One of the best written Star Wars stories ever made-Pretty Lightsabers-Strongly developed characters including the player character-Brilliant Force Powers-Decently Challenging-Awesome light and dark side choices-Amazing level up skill tree-Diverse gameplay options even though most of us go with jedi for the sake of our childhood-(Apathy is death)-Great Crafting systemCons:-(Forgot to add this) Getting a lightsaber takes a bit which kind of sucks but some might find this to be a good thing-Slow start (First 4 Hours)-Rushed ending (Last 2 Hours)-Inventory system is in need of a search bar you get a lot of garbage and have a lot of inventory space I think infinite-Cutscenes crash issues which for me were cured by windowed mode in certain cutscenes (Biggest issue in the whole game)-Lightsaber combat damage is really quick the damage to saber users have is too fast I personally just wanted longer fights because how epic they were.-Small abusable glitches nothing special-Not the brightest AI but not even near broken (Sorry if this isn't written that well i'm far from an English major)Overall Kotor II is the best Star Wars game I have ever played hands down and one of the best RPG games I have ever played it's one of my top 5 favorite games and if you get into it you'll understand why.9.5/10Try to get the original first if you can and playthrough it but if not this game can stand alone easily because of how good it is.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2013
												The best Star Wars game since Jedi Knight, and one of the greatest RPGs of all time. Now made even better with the latest patch! Buying KOTOR 2 on Steam means not only do you get an amazing RPG, written by the likes of Chris Avellone, but it also has full widescreen support, cloud saves and, yes, achievements.There's something new to be found in every playthrough, all play styles are catered for. Saber fighting or Force powers, it is possible to play either or mix up the two.Picking Light Side or Dark Side choices will affect how your companions develop through the game, but one of the most fascinating paths is the Neutral path - the one that Kreia endorses. Kreia is a fascinating character and has an excellent voice actor.Make sure you get The Sith Lords Restored Content mod from the Steam Workshop to get the full experience. If you want more, M4-78 restores some additional cut content, but it isn't necessary for a first playthrough.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												This game is a fun game, but only if you know what you're coming into. To get right down to the issue, this game is unfinished. Parts feel unpolished and incomplete. The game is glitchy and places and some of the events that happen in the game happen for no discernible reason. The first quarter of the game is pretty well done, but the instant you're able to travel to other planets, the game falls apart. The narrative is poor, most characters are poorly written and I don't think the game does a good job at providing you incentive to continue for the story's sake.That said, the gameplay, when it works, is absolutely fantastic. If you've played the first KOTOR and enjoyed the gameplay, this one is on a whole new levels. More force powers, more feats, prestige classes, being able to get your companions to change classes if you have enough influence (which in itself is a weird system that feels very wonky, but still). Mechanically, this game is fantastic in terms of combat. Also, though I've said most of the characters are poorly written, some of them are actually very well written. Kreia, Hanharr, and Atton being a few of my favorites. The characters never really say much, as their backstories could probably be contained to a two page document (with the exception being Kreia), but they still have good personalities.Overall, if you liked the first KOTOR for the story, I'd be wary. If you like the game for the gameplay as well, I'd definitely check this out, but make sure you have the restoration mod.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
Pros:-Immersive star wars role playing experience-Morality is more intricate than just light side/dark side this time-Wide range of character customization-Well developed companions-Weapon customization (you can have whatever lightsaber color you want!)-Large amount of content-Relatively high replayability-Nonlinear gameplay; player can choose to do the plots in whatever order they desire-HK-47 and all his quotesCons:-Cut content; Obsidian had to rush this game into retail, and had to cut a lot of content.  Thus, the plot has some noticeable gaps and seems choppy-Mild bugginess, but nothing game breakingOverall: First, it's worth mentioning that there is a Restored Content Mod that Obsidian took part in allowing.  This mod adds a lot of cut content, including an entire plot arc with HK-47, back into the game.  If you buy this, you should absolutely install that mod as well.That said, Obsidian took up the reins and did the series justice.  It's unfortunate that they had to rush the game near the end, because the plot is fantastic and really deserved to have its day.  But the gameplay is still fun, immersive, and captivating, and the amount of customiztaion for your character has only increased from the first game.  It's a pleasure to play, and rarely does the game become tedious.  Instead it's just a fun ride from start to finish.Bottom Line: Absolutely recommend

You start off as a man or woman on a mining asteroid with mo clue as to how you got there on this asteroid you meet Kreia who will become your mentor in the ways of the force and atton a dude whos a mercenary i guess. well it turns out your the last of the jedi and without spoiling anything everyone is out to get you.this game has an expansive Darkside-Lightside system that effects things from how much Mp a move takes up, if your lightside and you want to force choke someone well say goodbye to your mp cause its gonna take a hit, or maybe you want to heal yourself cause droids are destroying your body welp dont try to use force lightning later cause your mp is gonna be gone sucka. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												This is a deeply brilliant game, but it's flaws are real and present. the original release was brutally cut for financial reasons and released early, full of bugs and plot holes. it's derivative of the original and suffers a muddier plot, disjointed and abandoned story threads and muddled antagonists that don't drive the narrative. But there was clearly something here, and it was based on one of the best RPGs to date. Every game system is a refinement and extension of the first game; but more elegantly implemented and more polished.  The events and world of this story are natural outgrowths of the back-story or events of the first game;  but where the first game barely sketched the universe with stock characters, this game renders the fine details of the darkest days of the old republic with complex and compelling characters.This is a game that tells the aftermath of the hero's journey. Depicted is a galaxy limping off and winding down after the great blows struck by the Mandalorian wars (in the back-story to the first game) and the Jedi civil war (the last half of which are the events of the first game).  The more complicated plot hides multiple interlocking stories, telling many tragedies. the characters are all richly developed, but there are no simple heroes or outright villains. the heroes are all tragic, with deep character flaws that drive them more then the events.  There are no clear villains because even the villains are tragedies in their own right, deftly interwoven with the larger narrative, and each a demonstration of their failures and a warning of the danger of their paths. Years of work by the community have restored the cut content and revealed the ambitious pattern of story threads lost to budget and time. Community fixes have corrected bugs and fixed issues, even to the point of hex editing and reverse engineering. Even the developers have gotten into the act, releasing a patch 10 years after publication (and subsequent commercial failure) adding support for high resolution wide screen monitors, steam achievements, and workshop mods.Now we have a game that approaches realization of the ambition of the developers, and delivers on that narrative with competence, provided you're willing to take the time and spend the effort to breath with it. Taken on it's own, it's fractious and oppressive world is a cautionary tale of hubris, but when combined with the original, it's a dark counterbalance to that bright tale, putting both into sharp relief. This truly is the “Empire” to the original KotOR's “New Hope”. This is a deeply flawed game, but there is a genius beneath it's surface.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Awesome game, one of the best (along with the first KOTOR) star wars game out thereStory is interesting, so are the characters, your choices do affect the story and the outcomes of the different planets way more than in the first one imo, This game is dialogue heavy but you wont mind because that what makes this game so interesting. Your companion roster actually changes based on your light or dark side alignment, and they react to your actions as well, in a way that can change their personalities.There's tons of weapons (and light sabers, of course) that you can customize depending on your play style, more dmg? more blast fire reflect? More dmg base on your light side alignment? your pickThe strongest aspect of this game are the villains. Those Sith lords have awesome designs, backstories and powers. It shows that a lot of work went into creating themIts an awesome game, worth the price imoHowever there are some downsides, that i can't overlook in a reviewBiggest one: Its unfinished in some areas, and it shows. The developers were rushed to finish this game. There's a lot of dialogue/scenes/plot points that were deleted and that's a shame. Because of it, a lot of questions remain at the end of the game as certain plot lines never actually get a resolution, particularly one established at the beginning of the game2 planets are really a drag, and make me miss Taris from the first game (which is a drag to complete) Main reason is, since you're on one of those planets to solve a mystery that never completely gets solved, the whole area feels pointless Not playing as the character from the first game can be a disappointment for someSay what you will about Darth Malak, but he got a lot of screen time in the first game which makes us despise him even more. In this game, although one of those Lords gets a lot of attention, the equally interesting other Sith lords barely get any. Lastly, while the story of this game is better in a lot of areas compared to the first one,  the story of the first KOTOR felt, imo, a little more... epic, in proportionsNot a perfect game, but one thats definitly worth checking out. Still one of the greatest RPG's out there

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												I awoke in an unknown place in space, missing most of my clothes and armed with nothing but what swings between my legs. After a quick,  failed attempt to find pants I instead found a creepy old woman who insists she knows me. My God, what did I do last night? I immediately made a vow that would be the last time I drink at a cantina on an empty stomach. In my heart, though, my fingers were crossed.After wandering around an semi-abandoned mining station with this woman and a guy I had to restrain myself not to punch, we fled on a ship while running from arguably the ashiest man I had ever seen in my life. No amount of lotion in this galaxy could undo years of poor skin treatment. The ashy man said he knew the old woman, and it began to click...did I meet him last night too? I didn't...no...I wouldn't entertain the thought of touching such such dry, dry skin.If only all RPGs began like this and ended with me fighting with lightsabers. A must play for any Star Wars fan, as it teaches you the dangers of not moisturising your skin properly can lead to dire consequences.

Because of it, a lot of questions remain at the end of the game as certain plot lines never actually get a resolution, particularly one established at the beginning of the game2 planets are really a drag, and make me miss Taris from the first game (which is a drag to complete) Main reason is, since you're on one of those planets to solve a mystery that never completely gets solved, the whole area feels pointless Not playing as the character from the first game can be a disappointment for someSay what you will about Darth Malak, but he got a lot of screen time in the first game which makes us despise him even more. In this game, although one of those Lords gets a lot of attention, the equally interesting other Sith lords barely get any. Lastly, while the story of this game is better in a lot of areas compared to the first one,  the story of the first KOTOR felt, imo, a little more... epic, in proportionsNot a perfect game, but one thats definitly worth checking out. Still one of the greatest RPG's out there

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Best replay value of any story-based game I've ever played in my 35 years on this earth. I originally had this on Xbox back in the day and it was a popular replayable game for many years, then on PC with mods for many more years. I've played through this game about 1-2 times per year on average for over a decade and it still never really gets old (although certain parts do).   Maybe swap around some mods and decide to go a different direction with your light/dark side choices and which combination of companions to focus on and you get a completely different gaming experience. TSLRCM breathed new life into the game, and just added to that replay value by refreshing it and adding enough content to make it interesting again. The game has enough depth and variable that even with all those playthroughs I still find myself occasionally consulting a walkthrough or guide to get a hint or reminder how to unlock a particular plot point, piece of gear, etc.  I'd normally be loathe to pay more than about $5 for any game this old but it is still a great value at 2-3x that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3
												I really loved the first game, so I was excited to play this one. I have to admit, though, that the first time I played KOTOR II, I didn't enjoy it at all. Everything seemed opposite the first game; the planets felt more empty, and the companions all seemed like they had something to hide. It wasn't until I played through the game a second time that I realized what the fuss was about - you. In this game, you play as an exiled Jedi, whose force powers have been stripped by the Jedi council. As you progress through the game, you amass a great group of companions and gain back your force powers, influencing your companions with your alignment. At the end of the game, it's revealed that the exile is responsible for countless deaths, and was experiencing that pain throughout the game. It's almost as big a shock as the reveal in KOTOR I. the Exile's story is one of the most tragic in Star Wars, and Kreia is one of the best characters in Star Wars. This entire game dwells in the moral gray area of the Force, where few other Star Wars games or movies dare to go. Kreia in particular is the antithesis of what Star Wars should be, and that's exactly why she's so great. While I may love the original KOTOR, I have an immense amount of respect for this game, and in particular for Chris Avellone, who is one of the best video game writers of all time. This game is Amazing.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Got to play it again through the Star Wars Humble Bundle and with the Restored Content Mod (Which I highly recommend installing). The story is very exciting, expecially its message to the players on the influence of the force itself through the enigmatic character known as Kreia, who in my opininion is one of the most spectacularily written characters in a game. Also, in comparison to the previous title, the story offers the player much more food for thought, and follows a much more complex route than the traditional hero defeats villain formula that the previous title followed. In terms of characters, nothing has changed. They are all very memorable, unique, and full of life.Gameplay wise, it is an upgrade to the first with much better personalization and customization with more feats, and force powers. The game also improves upon the first with the introduction to new Jedi specializations which you may learn alongside the original three classes of Jedi.  With the amount of love it has recieved from the modding community, and with the memorable characters and companions along with their humorous dialogue, this may be the best Star Wars game to this day.10/10 would love to have another bad feeling about this again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												This may be the single most underrated video game of all time. In fairness, the original version (as I played it on my Xbox) was indeed a bit of a mess. I have no idea why this game was recently updated with full modern game amenities (steam cloud, achievements, controller support, workshop, etc) but it's one of the happiest gaming surprises I've ever experienced. Playing through this game again - this time with the restored content mod - was an awesome opportunity I never thought I would have.If the philosophy of Star Wars has ever interested you in a deeper way, this game was written for you. The way the story deconstructs the Force - what it means to be a Jedi, a Sith, what generalizations those titles reflect, and what meaning they contain is infinitely fascinating, and I find myself reflecting on the scenarios and characters introduced in this game more so than any other Star Wars property (and most science fiction in general).If you want to unravel the true mysteries of the Force - or just want to find out what happens after the first KotOR - this game is definitely worth your time.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2013
												The best Star Wars game since Jedi Knight, and one of the greatest RPGs of all time. Now made even better with the latest patch! Buying KOTOR 2 on Steam means not only do you get an amazing RPG, written by the likes of Chris Avellone, but it also has full widescreen support, cloud saves and, yes, achievements.There's something new to be found in every playthrough, all play styles are catered for. Saber fighting or Force powers, it is possible to play either or mix up the two.Picking Light Side or Dark Side choices will affect how your companions develop through the game, but one of the most fascinating paths is the Neutral path - the one that Kreia endorses. Kreia is a fascinating character and has an excellent voice actor.Make sure you get The Sith Lords Restored Content mod from the Steam Workshop to get the full experience. If you want more, M4-78 restores some additional cut content, but it isn't necessary for a first playthrough.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
Good Star Wars RPGStar Wars Knights of the Old Republic: The Sith Lords (KOTOR 2) is an RPG developed by Obsidian and sequel to Bioware's Knights of the Old rebulic (KOTOR 1). Renowned for being released unfinished and buggy, I chose to play the game with 'Restored Content Mod' (Fixes bugs and adds cut content), Glowing lightsabre (lightsabres look much better) just so I can get the best experience.The Good- Excellent soundtrack = Definitely reminds you of Star Wars.- Interesting characters = Your companions have a wide range of personalities, credits to Kreia and HK-47. - Plenty of armor and weapons = Your can waer light, medium or heavy armor (when you unlock the ability) which have unique perks. There  are tons of weapons including pistols, blaster rifles, grenades and lightsabres. Weapons and armor can also be upgraded to have various effects and efficiency.- Wide range of powers = You get a wide range of dark, light and universal jedi powers to play with.- Train jedi/sith = As you play the game you can impact your "influence" over party mmebers by either your dialogues with them or actions (when they are in the party). When you have enough infleunce and meet certain conditions, you can train your companions into Jedi or Sith, giving them a wide range of abilities and access to lightsabres.- Plenty of side quests = Each planet you travel to has plenty of things for you to do.- Darker atmosphere = The plot is alot darker than it's predecessor.- You can get lightsabre earlier = Unlike the first game where you can only get lightsabre mid/late game, in KOTOR 2 you are able to get your lightsabre early on if you go to certain planets first.- Better graphics = The animations and lighting look better than the original KOTOR- Controller support- Widescreen supportThe Bad- Still buggy = Got stuck (unable to move character) a few times while playing.- Ending not that great = Just didn't feel as good as the previous game.- Pazaak is a pain = Pazaak is a card game where you need to score higher than your opponent without busting (going higher than) 20. The draws are random and it can get frustrating since the game is linked to some side quests. There is a mod in workshop that makes it easier if your just want to progress through quests.- Swoop Racing isn't fun = Similar to the first game with a few alterations at different araes. The problem is that you need to get an almost perfect score to win (fastest time), which generally involves not colliding to anything and getting most boosts (or else you need to start from begging). There is a mod in workshop to make this easier as well.- Not Morally Grey enough = After you go to 'Nar Shadar', you are told that sometimes good actions can have offorseen consequences (such as when individual got mugged after giving him money). However whilst playing the game I found that this wasn't prevailent at all with 'Good' choices not having any consequences and vice versa.- Shorter than original KOTOR = There are fewer planets to explore than the previous game and gameplay was shorter.- Environments/map design isn't that great = I just didn't find them that interesting. They needed more things to make them feel more alive, like the previous KOTOR- HK Factory boring = (Restored content mod) This factory wasn't interesting at all and it was understandable why it was cut. It is also very difficult so you need to make sure you have plenty of repaire kist and items for HK-47. - Difficulty Curve = Also prevailent in previous game, sometimes you will face enemies which are a cakewalk to get through. Other times you'll be struggling to survive against the relentless horde.Overall, KOTOR 2 is a good RPG. It's improves upon the previous games in a few areas, though in others it takes a step backwards. I highly recommend you play this game with mods to get best experience.

												I didn't like this game at first. I had just finished Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic and was eager to try out the second game, a game a lot of people consider even better than the first. Excited to be absorbed into the Kotor universe again and to experience a new perspective of my favourite Era in Star Wars history.When I first played Kotor, I couldn't stop playing it. I started during a school break and entered a routine of waking up, eating, playing kotor, sleeping. But when I picked up Kotor II, I just couldn't get as invested. The tutorial was boring and lengthy and the first planet Telos was uninteresting. I stopped playing for a while.After a break I played the game again. I'm having a lot of fun now that I have lowered my standards and stopped comparing it to Kotor 1. Now that I have experienced the faults I can see all of the great strengths. My advice for you is to enter the game without raised standards and to accept the game as it is. You will find a fantastic RPG with great characters and an interesting premise.Also, use the Sith Lords Restored Content Mod.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												Only the greatest CRPG of all time! No, really.Well, maybe if you value things like 'not having bugs' or 'balanced gameplay' or 'not being rushed out the door for Christmas'. But, what classic CRPG (Bioware aside) isn't filled with these little character flaws? Frankly, it still feels more polished than Alpha Protocol, which, while remaining one of my favorite all-time games, doesn't have the 'rushed out' excuse so much.Despite being a licenced game and sequel, the story of the Jedi Exile and her companions (oh, did I mention the player character is canonically female?) manages to have the best narrative I've seen in any video game I've ever played, one which still sparks debate over its true messages and intent. Without giving too much away, you'll be touching on the nature of good and evil, the scars that remain from war, the struggle against objective morality and appointed fate, and the very real consequences that come from being a video game character. (No, really.)Also, this game both stands up to repeat paythroughs and doesn't make you hate the vast majority of the supporting cast. (LOOKING AT YOU, BIOWARE)More importantly, thanks to the good people at Aspyr and the dedicated mod community, the game has both the content it deserved to ship with and a slick control and graphical update for the modern gamer. Fully playable using a 360 controller, widescreen without stretching or patch hacks, and on whichever operating system you fancy most. (IN YOUR FACE, BIOWARE)Star Wars love not required, and perhaps detrimental! Being a person who hates Star Wars, I have to make the obvious admission that some fans of that saga might not like this game too much. That said, the depths of the story and its themes, and the ambiguity they bring, should make up for that...and to be sure, this game still packs a lot of love for the old hokey science-fantasy epic, all the same. (Also, I love other Star Wars games too, like the original Battlefront titles, so don't get too uppity.)TL;DR Made me a nihilist, Handmaiden best girl, 11/10.

												Finished the game twice 10 years ago, but it still feels like an epic game today.Going through the story again, and the latest patch, combined with the various mods you can find on the web make it one of the greatest RPG game ever. You can count on at least 15-20 hours of gameplay if you want to finish the game on 1 side of the force, while doing all the side quests.Nice story, more complex than the 1st one, and for any Star wars fan, it's a must have!Graphically, while not being impressive, it's still nice to play, but you don't play a Kotor for its graphics.Musics are nice and fit well in the universe.The only point I would have loved to see improved are the fighting animations, too few in my opinion. Definetely recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I played this game when it first came out on the XBox many years ago when it first came out, and like the first game, I loved it. When this appeared during the holiday sale, I decided I ought to have it on a current device and snatched it up. The game and story are still every bit as engrossing as I remember them, but I find the lack of controller support to be super-annoying. Furthermore, perhaps it is just my laptop, but graphical issues abound. I can't Alt-Tab without the program crashing (which means that any time I adjust the volume it crashes); it also crashes frequently during cutscenes. I am sure I could rectify some of these issues with some internet research and some editing of the .ini file, but I don't think I should HAVE to do that. I sort of expect the games to, y'know... work. The game itself is to be recommended, but I really have to grit my teeth and put up with the lackluster port.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												One of my favorite RPGs and probably the best story I've experienced in the Star Wars universe aside from maybe Empire Strikes Back. This story gives you a completely fresh set of characters (aside from HK-47 from the first game but his return is most welcome) and a fresh story that isn't simply copying wholesale from the movies. The game challenges the broad themes we see in other Star Wars stories while still absolutely feeling like its a part of that setting.I don't have a lot to say about the game play. Obsidian did the best they could with what they were given. I like the way you can unlock abilities for yourself and others in your crew through repeated interactions. If you've played any old school rpgs, the gameplay should be adequate, being based on d20 rules. You at least get some choice for how you level but you always have the option to autolevel if you don't want to fool around with it. You're really here for the story anyway.  And I have to tip my hat to the makers of The Restored Content Mod which, as other reviewers note, is absolutely essential. Google it, download it. I'm on my third playthrough coming back to this game after some months and the Restored Content Mod has been updated to version 1.8.3 in the interim. With this version of the mod, the experience is very minimal on bugs. The only crashes I've had could be attributed to other improperly installed content mods. Aside from this, I recommend googling to find the widescreen solution for this game. It takes a little work sadly to get this game to support modern monitor resolutions (if your monitor is 4 by 3 aspect ratio, you should be fine but if you're using a 16 by 9 or 16 by 10 and you don't want your characters to look bloated, google the widescreen fix and then the minimap fix for the widescreen fix.) So yeah, some up front work to be done but this game is 10 bucks and IMO, even with the extra work, its going to be the best ten bucks you'll spend on an rpg outside of Fallout New Vegas.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												First and foremost is the clarification: this is a very long yet well-made game that is absolutely a successor to the first Knights of the Old Republic. I have only done one playthrough and it took me more than 65 hours to complete. It has all of the features of the original game and has added many new ones that seamlessly integrate with this second entry in the series. The story is rich and in-depth and the characters are memorable for the most part but feel a little flatter in this game than they did in the first. It also cleverly uses mechanics so that you can compete missions and fights in a variety of fashions and lots of your choices have very visible effects, but not all of them. Overall, this is a good game.HOWEVER, I played the first KOTOR on my smartphone and I must say I prefer that one easily over this one, though for mostly personal reasons. The story of the first one felt tighter and more polished whereas with this game it feels like they tried to stretch it out for no good reason. I felt plagued by unnecessarily long fights as a result of too many enemies and zones that are large but I couldn't see the reason why they had to be so large. I also am a completionist so I try to do every sidequest possible and so quickly became annoyed with the constant trecking and back-tracking all over every map. There is also the fact that the characters are there but feel flatter and less developed than they did in the first game; they also don't feel like they are crucial part of stroy like they did in the first game. Finally is the fact that this story just doesn't feel as good as the one from the first KOTOR. I felt like it left too many loose ends, the plot twists fell flat, and it just plain left me feeling unsatisfied as compared to the first entry there just isn't a sense of closure.Now, a lot of this has to do with personal taste and so someone else might completely disagree. As for bugginess I didn't encounter any bugs, glitches, etc. during my playthrough.In conclusion: I would recommend the game, but I'm worried you'll feel less satisfied if you've already played the first KOTOR.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												NOTE: This review is a redux of my original review.Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords is made by Obisidian Entertainment and serves as a sequel to Bioware's Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. I've played through this game twice. My first playthrough was on the Jedi path and without the Restored Content and M4-78 mods. Honestly, I didn't like it and I wrote a negative review on it. However, after some time had passed, I tried the game again, but I went down the path of a Dark Jedi and had the previously stated mods installed. This review is based on my second playthrough:Pros:+Slightly better graphics than KOTOR I+Story is decent and more clear thanks to the RCM and M4-78 but does have some minor issues.+Details of the environments surpasses KOTOR I+Like the idea of influence and converting your party to be a Jedi or Dark Jedi+Well designed characters, but I felt their backstories weren't as fleshed out as in KOTOR I (however there are some exceptions to this criticism)+Maintained alot of elements that made KOTOR I great (choice / morale system, path of Jedi or Sith, etc)+Mods like the Restored Content Modification and M4-78 fix most of the problems found in the "Vanilla version" of the game. (Hats off to the people who developed the mods)Cons: -The turn-based combat (like in my KOTOR I review, this is something I don't like in RPGs in general)-The ending (those of you who've played the game know what I'm talking about)-The influence and Jedi conversion can be VERY tedious as some characters aren't as easy to convert / influence-I was a bit disappointed that the story didn't really relate much to KOTOR I as I thought it would be. The story is connected to KOTOR I by characters from the previous game but kinda are like side characters and refernces to events and other characters from the previous game.Overall, (8/10) Star Wars KOTOR II: The Sith Lords is a solid game but (in my opinion) not as good as the original. However, its still worth a try if your a die hard Star Wars fan or an RPG fan. NOTE: If you want the best version of this game get: 1. The Restored Content Mod, 2. M4-78, 3. Visas HD Re-Skin from the Steam Workshop.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												What can I say?.. It's good 'ol KOTOR.. Not as polished as the first, but that's what The Sith Lords: Restored Content Mod is for. Download that and you will be set to start on your tale of heriosm or villiany in a broken galaxy far, far away.. This game is a fantastic addition to the KOTOR family and sadly the last. It improves upon much of the mechanics of the first KOTOR, adds a great cast of new and some old companions, nice locations to visit, and a great continuation of the storyline we loved.Sadly, you can feel how frenzied they were to get this out the door. In it's unmodded state it is lacking both in a finished story and 2-3 extra planets/missions. It was cast aside when it was released but, years later it has made a triumphant return and finally got the love and attetion it deserved from a great community of players and modders.In summary 7.5/10 in release-state and 9/10 with the restored content mod. So go ahead an pick this up for yourself and make sure to download TSL:RCM.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												TL;DRA Noir setting in the Star Wars universe. Need I say more?Honestly I enjoyed this game much more than the original.With the Restored Content Mod (which is super easy to download in case anyone has trepidation over downloading something from another site to make your game better) I can honestly say this is my favorite game of all time. In my opinion the reason why this game is so amazing is because all of the party members are so interesting and so well fleshed out that the only thing I can tell you without spoiling anything is if I had to make a top ten favorite video game characters of all time list, I know at least two characters from this game would be on it. One reason why I like this game so much more than the first one is because, again, without spoiling anything, the main character of the original KOTOR doesn't feel like an actual "character" until around 80% into the game, until then you're kind of just a blank slate. In this game however, you're a broken jedi with borderline PTSD. How cool does that sound? In this game your party members evolve and change personalities depending on how much influence you have with them. Its an amazing system that can change the core ideals of party members with whom you've curryed favor, and without spoiling anything, (getting kind of hard not to spoil this fantastic game haha), can lead some of these characters to become "something greater".On top of this, It also has a fantastically ominous and foreboding atmosphere not unlike Dark Souls of all games. This is a top notch game that checks all the right boxes to create a cinematic experience like no other. It opened my eyes and got me to think in a very different way that has pretty much effected the way I play all my games with morality systems to date: some times neither good nor evil are the way to go, its best to remain gray.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												(PROTIP: If you plan to buy KOTOR 2 for PC, you should, beyond a reasonable doubt, download and install the Restored Content mod. Since Obsidian rushed KOTOR 2's release for the holiday season, they had to cut out parts of this game, most of which were pretty integral to the plot.)Synopsis: You, the player, are The Exile (canonically a woman named Meetra Surik). Like many of your fellow Jedi, you followed Revan to help the Republic during the Mandalorian Wars. Revan, who was impressed with your combat prowess, decided to appoint you as one of his top generals.The final battle of the Mandalorian Wars took place near the Sith planet of Malachor V. Since the rest of the Republic's fleet could make it to the battle in time, you decide to utilize the Republic's ultimate weapon: The Mass Shadow Generator, designed by the Zabrak technician Bao-Dur. The Mass Shadow Generator activates, pulling the planet, the Mandalorian armada and the Republic fleet into a gravity field. The death of the planet and all parties involved was so great that it gave you a Wound in The Force, severing and deafening your connection to The Force.However, unlike the rest of your Jedi colleagues, you were the only one who did not fall to the Dark Side. When the war was over, you decided to return to the Jedi Council on Coruscant to face judgement. The Council, both butt furious over your insubordination and incredulous at your voluntary return unanimously chose to banhammer you from The Order. You were then exiled to wander the outer reaches of the Galaxy. Oh, and they took your lightsaber as well.-Fast forward five years later. The war with Darth Malak and the Sith was so costly the Republic can barely defend itself. Strange, phantom-like Sith assassins have dogged the Jedi, hunting them down in an effort to completely destroy the Jedi Order. The crime syndicate known as "The Exchange" has put out a bounty for any live Jedi. Strange, durasteel droids have integrated themselves into the Republic government. Meanwhile, the Republic attempts to rebuild Telos IV, a planet bombarded to near destruction by the Sith Admiral Saul Karath. An unknown figure contacts Republic Admiral Carth Onasi, requesting that you be brought from the Outer Rim to act as a diplomat to Telos. Who made the request, and why, are a mystery to you, but other external forces have plans for you...

												This is one of the most immersive titles from the franchise. The story is brilliant and twists and turns constantly, leaving you with a dawning understanding of something world shaking taking place as you play through the game. Obviously good or evil decisions are mixed in with more subtle or subjective choices meaning that this can be role played properly if you wish and with so many choices throughout the story line it makes it replayable enjoyable for a long time to come. The interface is a little aged but once you get used to it you will be immersed in the story and universe before you know it.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												First and foremost is the clarification: this is a very long yet well-made game that is absolutely a successor to the first Knights of the Old Republic. I have only done one playthrough and it took me more than 65 hours to complete. It has all of the features of the original game and has added many new ones that seamlessly integrate with this second entry in the series. The story is rich and in-depth and the characters are memorable for the most part but feel a little flatter in this game than they did in the first. It also cleverly uses mechanics so that you can compete missions and fights in a variety of fashions and lots of your choices have very visible effects, but not all of them. Overall, this is a good game.HOWEVER, I played the first KOTOR on my smartphone and I must say I prefer that one easily over this one, though for mostly personal reasons. The story of the first one felt tighter and more polished whereas with this game it feels like they tried to stretch it out for no good reason. I felt plagued by unnecessarily long fights as a result of too many enemies and zones that are large but I couldn't see the reason why they had to be so large. I also am a completionist so I try to do every sidequest possible and so quickly became annoyed with the constant trecking and back-tracking all over every map. There is also the fact that the characters are there but feel flatter and less developed than they did in the first game; they also don't feel like they are crucial part of stroy like they did in the first game. Finally is the fact that this story just doesn't feel as good as the one from the first KOTOR. I felt like it left too many loose ends, the plot twists fell flat, and it just plain left me feeling unsatisfied as compared to the first entry there just isn't a sense of closure.Now, a lot of this has to do with personal taste and so someone else might completely disagree. As for bugginess I didn't encounter any bugs, glitches, etc. during my playthrough.In conclusion: I would recommend the game, but I'm worried you'll feel less satisfied if you've already played the first KOTOR.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												NOTE: This review is a redux of my original review.Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords is made by Obisidian Entertainment and serves as a sequel to Bioware's Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. I've played through this game twice. My first playthrough was on the Jedi path and without the Restored Content and M4-78 mods. Honestly, I didn't like it and I wrote a negative review on it. However, after some time had passed, I tried the game again, but I went down the path of a Dark Jedi and had the previously stated mods installed. This review is based on my second playthrough:Pros:+Slightly better graphics than KOTOR I+Story is decent and more clear thanks to the RCM and M4-78 but does have some minor issues.+Details of the environments surpasses KOTOR I+Like the idea of influence and converting your party to be a Jedi or Dark Jedi+Well designed characters, but I felt their backstories weren't as fleshed out as in KOTOR I (however there are some exceptions to this criticism)+Maintained alot of elements that made KOTOR I great (choice / morale system, path of Jedi or Sith, etc)+Mods like the Restored Content Modification and M4-78 fix most of the problems found in the "Vanilla version" of the game. (Hats off to the people who developed the mods)Cons: -The turn-based combat (like in my KOTOR I review, this is something I don't like in RPGs in general)-The ending (those of you who've played the game know what I'm talking about)-The influence and Jedi conversion can be VERY tedious as some characters aren't as easy to convert / influence-I was a bit disappointed that the story didn't really relate much to KOTOR I as I thought it would be. The story is connected to KOTOR I by characters from the previous game but kinda are like side characters and refernces to events and other characters from the previous game.Overall, (8/10) Star Wars KOTOR II: The Sith Lords is a solid game but (in my opinion) not as good as the original. However, its still worth a try if your a die hard Star Wars fan or an RPG fan. NOTE: If you want the best version of this game get: 1. The Restored Content Mod, 2. M4-78, 3. Visas HD Re-Skin from the Steam Workshop.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												Hk-47 is back.Nuff said, game on meatbags.Seriously though, if you like Star Wars then definitely play this. Personally I'd say the story isn't as good as the first KotOR, but the new gameplay changes more than make up for this.-You can upgrade any weapon or armour in the game, unless it says otherwise. Plus you can CRAFT upgrades for them depending on your skills anytime you want at a workbench. The previous game would only let you upgrade certain items, mainly just "Unique" items such as "Mission's Vibroblade" or "Zalbaar's Bowcaster" or whatever, you get what I mean anyway.-Influence your companions.Hell this change alone is awesome! Do you like being the biggest jerk in the universe? Well now you can drag your companions down with you. Do you like to pretend you're Jesus and help every and anyone you possibly can? Well fear not, your companions still make comments to stroke your ego, puny Jedi.There's more but just bloody jump in already.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												What can I say?.. It's good 'ol KOTOR.. Not as polished as the first, but that's what The Sith Lords: Restored Content Mod is for. Download that and you will be set to start on your tale of heriosm or villiany in a broken galaxy far, far away.. This game is a fantastic addition to the KOTOR family and sadly the last. It improves upon much of the mechanics of the first KOTOR, adds a great cast of new and some old companions, nice locations to visit, and a great continuation of the storyline we loved.Sadly, you can feel how frenzied they were to get this out the door. In it's unmodded state it is lacking both in a finished story and 2-3 extra planets/missions. It was cast aside when it was released but, years later it has made a triumphant return and finally got the love and attetion it deserved from a great community of players and modders.In summary 7.5/10 in release-state and 9/10 with the restored content mod. So go ahead an pick this up for yourself and make sure to download TSL:RCM.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Star Wars: KOTOR II TSL is a classic game. The story is good, and picks up some time after the events of the first game. When I first bought this game it had 7 CD's to install so having the digital version is convenient and more reliable too. I initially made the mistake of playing this game first so if you are purchasing this game I recommend that you go and play Star Wars: KOTOR 1 first. Fans of the SWTOR MMO should also play KOTOR 1 first because it deals with Revan and the story is more relevant to the MMO. This game puts you in the shoes of the Jedi Exile and your plot-convenient amnesia as you piece together who you are while regaining the force and making critical decisions. These decisions impact your party which is an improvement over the first game's mechanics but the story isn't as groundbreaking as the first KOTOR game. I always blamed Obsidian for rushing this game, but in reality they were the ones who were prodded along to finish the game and produced a great Star Wars classic that managed to fill the shoes of the original game. It's worth the money and time to play this game if you're a Star Wars fan, and an RPG fan. The combat is fun and the story is good. Replay value is high.
